questions.question_text:
What is the expected behavior of the following code?
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
my_list = [i for i in range(5)]
m = [my_list[i] for i in range(4,0,-1)] if my_list[i] %2 != 0]
print(m)
output -> SyntaxError: unmatched ']'
Ans -> B
The answer is right B tested

Based on the exact code presented the correct answer is B, if you remove the ']' from the code obviously the answer becomes [3,1] BUT the fact is ']' exists in the code so you must select B as the correct answer and nor speculate on 'what if's'

Selected Answer: C
In [89]: mylist = [ i for i in range(5)]

In [90]: mylist
Out[90]: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

In [91]: m = [mylist[i] for i in range (4,0,-1) if mylist[i] % 2!=0 ]

In [92]: m
Out[92]: [3, 1]
If there is no "]" after the for loop then, C would be the answer. Otherwise, "]" cause the error and answer will be B

Selected Answer: B
B: There's an ']' before 'if' statement so the code is erroneous

If that wasn't the case, the [3, 1] would be printed

Selected Answer: C
C. I suppose there is a typo error in the transcription

Selected Answer: B
B. the code is erroneous and it will not execute

>>> print(m)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B. a != b
C. a is not None

Example Closure , 

def f(x, y):
 nom, denom = x, y
 def g():
 return nom / denom
 return g

a = f(1, 2)
b = f(3, 4)

fun1 = a
fun2 = b

print(fun1())
print(fun2())

Selected Answer: BC
def f(x,y):
 nom,denom = x,y
 def g():
 return nom/denom
 return g

a=f(1,2)
b=f(3,4)

print(a is not None)
print(a!=b)
print(a() == 4)
print(b() == 4)

B,C

questions.question_text:
Assuming that the following code has been executed successfully, which of the expressions evaluate to True? (Choose two.)
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
For you who thought it was AD, here is the explanation:
When you have an array in a variable and set it to another variable, they share the same id, that means they point to the same array.
a = [1]
b = a
print(id(a), id(b)) # same id
Since a==b, when you set a[0] = 0, you are "also" doing b[0] = 0

A and C are correct.

a = [1]
b = a
a[0] = 0
print(len(a) == len(b)) # True
print(a[0] == b[0]) # True

Selected Answer: AC
A and C are correct

Selected Answer: AC
Selected Answer: A. len(a) == len(b)
C. a[0] == b[0]

Selected Answer: AC
a=[1]
b=a
a[0]=0
print(len(a)==len(b))#True
print(b[0]+1 == a[0])#False
print(a[0] == b[0])#True
print(a[0]+1 == b[0])#False

Ans is A,C

Selected Answer: AD
After executing the snippet:
a = a[0] = 0
b = b[0] = 1
A and C are correct

Selected Answer: AC
if you print(b[0]) it will print 0, so the answer is A and C.

b=a
a[0]=0
print(len(a) == len(b)) -> True
print(a[0] == b[0]) --> True
print(b[0] + 1 == a[0]) --> False
print(a[0] + 1 == b[0]) --> False

My answer is A and C

questions.question_text:
What is the expected output of the following code?
//IMG//
Which of the following lambda definitions are correct? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A. lambda x,y: (x,y)
C. lambda x,y: x//y - x%y

#question 111
#lambda x,y = x//y - x%y#SyntaxError: invalid syntax
lambda x,y: (x,y)
#lambda x,y: return x//y - x%y#SyntaxError: invalid syntax
lambda x,y: x//y - x%y

Tested: A,C
The answer is A,C
